content.html_value:
In addition to using the name America, we will also refer to the continent as Abya Yala, a term used by the indigenous peoples of the continent (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, , pp. 39-43).

Description

Certain events mark the history of humanity, but they are often told only from a single perspective. In the following texts, we present not just one, but different versions of the same event, in order to reach an understanding closer to the reality of what truly happened.

Events may be updated or new ones added at any time as a result of ongoing research.

value.name: Indigenous Peoples of Abya Yala (America)
value.desc: We study how Indigenous peoples arrived in Abya Yala (the Americas) and how they see themselves as part of a single family.

value.name: Lem/Leme
value.desc: We analyze the role of the Lem family as witnesses to the Treaty of Tordesillas, which, in a way, “divided” the world.

value.name: Who really discovered America (Abya Yala)?
value.desc: This question may seem simple at first glance, and a common answer is found in history books. However, what is often presented reflects only a single worldview.

value.name: Slavery overview
value.desc: Unfortunately, slavery was part of human history for millennia, and its effects are still felt today.

value.name: Banu Qasi
value.desc: We investigate how conflicts between the Banu Qasi and the Vikings led to the relationship between Lubb ibn Musa and Ayab, an enslaved woman.

value.name: Joaquina Cabra Family
value.desc: We study the life of Anastacia, who, like her mother, was enslaved, though it was never possible to identify her father.

value.name: Slavery among the Visigoths
value.desc: The 16th Council of Toledo, held under King Egica, describes the condition of several enslaved people, including women.

value.name: Slavery of the Carijó Indigenous People
value.desc: The enslavement of the Carijós led thousands to their deaths and to the disappearance of their culture.

value.name: Who said Indigenous peoples are different?
value.desc: We explore how the Church and colonizers treated Indigenous peoples as inferior beings, thereby legitimizing their enslavement.

value.name: Persecuted for a different faith
value.desc: The Visigoths persecuted Jews and Arians for their differing beliefs.

value.name: The Leme family and the Jews
value.desc: Although some 20th-century works mistakenly labeled the Leme as Jews, by taking phrases out of context, documents show that from the 15th to the 18th century what they actually did was hand Jews over to religious persecution.

value.name: Joaquina Cabra Family
value.desc: Several families were enslaved solely for being Black, and there were attempts to erase their historical records to, among other things, deny them reparations.

value.name: Attack against the Leme
value.desc: During the Paulista Civil War, the Camargo family falsely accused the Leme of being Jews, in order to draw popular anger and the Inquisition against them.

value.name: The attempt to cleanse the Visigoth image
value.desc: The Visigoths committed terrible acts against the Iberian population, as contemporary documents reveal. This led the people to seek external help from the Muslims. Even so, centuries later, Muslims were treated as invaders.
